references: the learning process involved in RFL into two steps: (1)
Specifically, the LoJ step pushes ML on the entire joined table to each (virtual) vertical table
instead of the vertical partition of the joined table. This step involves a
to avoid actual joins and unions, and it employs optimization strategies that can significantly reduce the computation and communication complexities (from
is the length of the joined table and
denotes the length of each vertical table
). For each learning problem on the vertical table
resulted from the LoJ step, the LoU step further pushes ML computation to each horizontal table
coordinates the LoJ and LoU computation on vertical/horizontal tables using a server-client architecture (detailed in Section

is partitioned into local models that are stored within individual clients. The server performs global server-side computation and coordinates the computation across clients, while clients perform client-side computation with local model updates.
RFL framework in the sense that it allows for integrating with various genres of learning algorithm. We demonstrate this by illustrating how to integrate
with two commonly used algorithms, SGD and ADMM.

S3.T2.caption: Table 2. The problem decomposition for LoJ, using SGD and ADMM with computation/communication reduction.
references:
(1) SGD. 
We can decompose the optimization problem of Eq. 2 into two sub-problems, by the chain rule ∇θiℓj=∂ℓj∂hi,j​∂hi,j∂θisubscript∇subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptℓ𝑗subscriptℓ𝑗subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗subscript𝜃𝑖\nabla_{\theta_{i}}\ell_{j}=\frac{\partial\ell_{j}}{\partial h_{i,j}}\frac{\partial h_{i,j}}{\partial\theta_{i}}.
The first sub-problem is to compute the partial derivative of ℓjsubscriptℓ𝑗\ell_{j} w.r.t. hi,jsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗h_{i,j} as ∂ℓj∂hi,jsubscriptℓ𝑗subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗\frac{\partial\ell_{j}}{\partial h_{i,j}} on the server side, since the server can obtain all the model predictions hi,jsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗h_{i,j} from clients.
The second sub-problem is to compute the partial derivative of hi,jsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗h_{i,j} w.r.t. θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} as ∂hi,j∂θisubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗subscript𝜃𝑖\frac{\partial h_{i,j}}{\partial\theta_{i}} on the client side. Consequently, the client with Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} can compute ∇θiℓjsubscript∇subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptℓ𝑗\nabla_{\theta_{i}}\ell_{j}
after receiving the ∂ℓj∂hi,jsubscriptℓ𝑗subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗\frac{\partial\ell_{j}}{\partial h_{i,j}} from the server, and further compute the gradient of Eq. 2 as ∇θiF​(Ti)subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑖𝐹subscript𝑇𝑖\nabla_{\theta_{i}}F(T_{i}) using Eq. 2 shown in Table 2. Finally, the client with Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} can update its local θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} using Eq. 2 with learning rate η𝜂\eta.
Now we have pushed the LoJ problem down to each vertical Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} associated with client-side computation of Eq. 2 and Eq. 2, alongside server-side computation of Eq. 2.
We can also use mini-batch SGD to perform these equations, by randomly subsampling a batch B𝐵B from N𝑁N and change N𝑁N to B𝐵B in each equation. However, the client-side computation complexity remains 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N).

We then add a quadratic term to the Lagrangian of Eq. 3, known as augmented Lagrangian (Boyd et al., 2011). After that, we can solve the optimization problem using ADMM with three update steps, including the server-side z𝑧z-update and λ𝜆\lambda-update (Eq. 2 and 2), as well as the client-side θ𝜃\theta-update (Eq. 2), as shown in Table 2.
In these equations, the form of atsuperscript𝑎𝑡a^{t} refers to the value of a𝑎a in the t𝑡t-th epoch, while ρ∈ℝ𝜌ℝ\rho\in\mathbb{R} is a penalty parameter that can be tuned.
{λj}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜆𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{\lambda_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N} are dual variables and λj∈ℝdcsubscript𝜆𝑗superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑐\lambda_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{c}}.
The {si,j}j=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗𝑗1𝑁\{s_{i,j}\}_{j=1}^{N} are residual variables for each table Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}, where si,j=∑k=1,k≠iMfi​(θk;Tk,pk​(j))−zjsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑘1𝑘𝑖𝑀subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝑇𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗s_{i,j}=\sum_{k=1,k\neq i}^{M}f_{i}(\theta_{k};T_{k,p_{k}(j)})-z_{j}.
This decomposition pushes independent optimization problems (i.e., θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}-update) to each vertical table Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}, which requires less frequent communication with the server (only after the θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}-update finishes) compared to the (mini-batch) SGD.

references:
We can now use consensus ADMM to solve this optimization problem with three update steps (Table 3).
Here, θiτ¯¯superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝜏\overline{\theta_{i}^{\tau}} is the average of {θiq,τ}q∈[Qi]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑞𝜏𝑞delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑖\{\theta_{i}^{q,\tau}\}_{q\in[Q_{i}]} and uiτ−1¯¯superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝜏1\overline{u_{i}^{\tau-1}} is the average of {uiq,τ−1}q∈[Qi]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑞𝜏1𝑞delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑖\{u_{i}^{q,\tau-1}\}_{q\in[Q_{i}]}, where uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} is the scaled dual variable and τ𝜏\tau denotes the τ𝜏\tau-th epoch of the horizontal ADMM.
The coordinator performs w𝑤w-update and the u𝑢u-update, while each client q𝑞q that owns Tiqsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑞T_{i}^{q} can perform the θiqsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑞\theta_{i}^{q}-update.
During each epoch of the horizontal ADMM, each client q𝑞q sends its updated θiqsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑞\theta_{i}^{q} to the coordinator and the coordinator returns wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and uiqsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑞u_{i}^{q} to the client q𝑞q for model update with one round of communication.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4. The physical operators with computation and communication functions, which cover both SGD and ADMM.
S4.T4.table:
Operator Function SGD ADMM
LoJ operator gather() model predictions model predictions
compute() Eq. 2, 2 Eq. 2, 2, 2, 2
scatter() partial derivatives auxiliary variables
LoU operator gather() model predictions, model predictions,
partial gradients model parameters
compute() Eq. 3 Eq. 3 and Eq. 3
scatter() aggregated gradients auxiliary variables
Client operator send() model predictions, model predictions,
partial gradients model parameters
receive() aggregated gradients auxiliary variables
compute() Eq. 3 and  3 Eq. 3
references:
We illustrate the training process in Algorithm 1.
which mainly consists of two loops: (1) the outer loop that conducts learning over join (LoJ) and (2) the inner loop that performs learning over union (LoU). To implement and unify the training processes of SGD and ADMM, we design three physical operators that abstract the computation and communication of TablePuppet.
The three operators include a LoJ operator, a LoU operator, and a client operator for client-side model updates.
As shown in Table 4, each operator contains three functions, including a compute​()compute\emph{compute}() for the computation, as well as gather/scatter​()gather/scatter\emph{gather/scatter}() or send/receive​()send/receive\emph{send/receive}() for the communication.

By combining the three physical operators in various ways and adjusting the implementations of their inner functions, we can implement SGD/ADMM not only for RFL but also for FL atop the vertical tables being joined (without the horizontal partitions).
For ease of exposition, we call this special case RFL-V in the rest of this paper.
As shown in Table 5, for RFL-V where each organization only has one client, we can just combine the LoJ operator and the client operator to implement RFL-SGD-V and RFL-ADMM-V.
For RFL, we use all three operators with functions shown in Table 4 to implement RFL-SGD and RFL-ADMM.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5. The SGD and ADMM algorithms atop TablePuppet.
S4.T5.table:
Scenario Algorithm Implementation of operators
RFL-V RFL-SGD-V LoJ: Eq. 2, 2, Client: Eq. 2, 2
RFL-ADMM-V LoJ: Eq. 2, 2, 2, 2, Client: Eq. 2
RFL RFL-SGD As that in Table 4 (SGD column)
RFL-ADMM As that in Table 4 (ADMM column)
references:
By combining the three physical operators in various ways and adjusting the implementations of their inner functions, we can implement SGD/ADMM not only for RFL but also for FL atop the vertical tables being joined (without the horizontal partitions).
For ease of exposition, we call this special case RFL-V in the rest of this paper.
As shown in Table 5, for RFL-V where each organization only has one client, we can just combine the LoJ operator and the client operator to implement RFL-SGD-V and RFL-ADMM-V.
For RFL, we use all three operators with functions shown in Table 4 to implement RFL-SGD and RFL-ADMM.

Table 6 summarizes the computation and communication complexity of the SGD/ADMM algorithms atop TablePuppet, in comparison with traditional VFL methods (VFL-SGD and VFL-ADMM), which are hypothetically assumed to be running on the vertical partitions of the entire joined table.
For simplicity, we omit the complexity analysis of the table-mapping mechanism in Table 6. We also represent the computation/communication complexity in terms of the tuple number (e.g., N𝑁N and nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}), since other parameters, such as feature dimension (e.g., disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}), are correlated with the tuple number.
